stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream debugging a crash in Course 15’s snowflake particle system, optimising memory/vertex allocation, and re-evaluating the level’s ‘styrofoam snow’ visual. He also prototypes new platform layouts (tilt bridges, zipper to a hidden hell area) and discusses broad performance work (overdraw cuts, anti-aliasing, mip-maps).

development_findings.summary: Course 15 is now the main blocker; a snowflake particle bug caused emulator crashes and revealed a missing ‘×4’ in vertex-buffer allocation that corrupted memory.
development_findings.quote: It’s like it’s missing the multiply by four here. Okay, so that mystery is solved.

development_findings.summary: Project 64 crashed when an inline function handled snow allocation; moving the code into a separate function prevented the crash, indicating an emulator quirk rather than game bug.
development_findings.quote: How does changing the function from an inline to not an inline make it work? This garbage emulator, man.

development_findings.summary: Real N64 hardware and most emulators run fine; only Parallel Launcher and some PJ64 builds fail. Kaze considers officially recommending Project 64 1.6 or real hardware for release.

Styrofoam ‘normal-mapped’ snow both crashes and looks wrong; Kaze and Biobak decide to scrap it. New plan: snow becomes flat cardboard with stapled white paper edges; normal-map effect may stay only on grass.
development_findings.quote: Do we even want the normal map styrofoam? I don't think it does look good.

development_findings.summary: Shell texturing is used but only on small actors due to heavy performance cost.
development_findings.quote: Shell texturing is extremely expensive… we’ve used it in some places, but only on small actors.

development_findings.summary: Tilt-bridge platforms implemented; Kaze tunes speed and width for difficulty and tests with input latency.
‘Zipper to hell’ secret entrance positioned; additional spring platform added for accessibility.
Planned geometry culling: cut holes under overhanging cardboard and give mountains their own material to reduce RDP time (currently ~40 ms).
Anti-aliasing toggle gives ~3 fps gain (23→26); mip-maps added selectively but limit combiners.
ROM is targeted to fit exactly 64 MB; final build teased as the “first quadruple-A N64 game.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze is frustrated by power outages, stream view losses, and emulator instability.
context_findings.quote: I'm so pissed, you guys have no idea… whenever that happens, your view count just drops back to zero.

context_findings.summary: He refuses to give release dates; repeated questions irritate him.
context_findings.quote: It’s all RTYI and it’s getting close to completion. Please stop asking me for release dates. I will literally lose my mind.

context_findings.summary: Main employment is external programming job; ROM-hack is hobby that requires monetised videos and streams.
context_findings.quote: It was up to me, I just wouldn't make videos at all, but then I can't do my thing as a hobby that makes money.

context_findings.summary: Explores Twitter ad-share and YouTube revenue; jokes about earning ‘50 cents’ per viral reply.
Philosophy: prioritises hardware accuracy; would rather change recommended emulator than alter valid code.
context_findings.quote: What if we force people to stop using Parallel? What if we just say Parallel is too inaccurate – use Project 64 1.6 or real N64.

context_findings.summary: Marketing line: intends to brand RTYI as “the first quadruple A N64 game ever.”
Legal awareness: would need to strip Mario IP for a commercial Steam release; acknowledges Nintendo risk.
context_findings.quote: If I were to release this game on Steam, obviously I would have to remove all the Mario assets though.

biobak.summary: Proposed replacing styrofoam snow with cardboard sheets stapled with white paper edging; Kaze accepts and adds to task list.
Suggested bubble-wrap area where popping nine bubbles yields a Yoshi coin; Kaze adds to to-do.
Recommends trimming hidden geometry / adding darker rim around void to save RDP time; Kaze begins implementing.

zeina.summary: A friend of Zeina installed the HDMI ‘N64 Digital’ mod in Kaze’s console; Zeina otherwise not involved this session.

key_stories.title: The Snowflake Crash Mystery
key_stories.summary: Snow particle effects in Course 15 repeatedly crashed Project 64, halting progress.
key_stories.challenge: Unknown crashes during snow rendering made level unplayable in main dev emulator.
key_stories.process: Kaze inspected assembly, found vertex-buffer mis-allocation (missing ×4) and tried moving an inline function out to isolate emulator issues.
key_stories.outcome: Bug is fixed on real hardware; Project 64 works when function is non-inline; memory corruption resolved.
key_stories.key_quote: This garbage emulator man, I swear.

key_stories.title: Styrofoam Snow Redesign
key_stories.summary: The stylish normal-mapped styrofoam snow caused visual issues and performance hits.
key_stories.challenge: Effect looked bad and sometimes crashed due to complex shaders and overdraw.
key_stories.process: Kaze debated merits, Biobak suggested replacing with simpler cardboard + stapled paper aesthetic.
key_stories.outcome: Decision made to scrap styrofoam effect, restrict normal-maps to grass, and implement new visual with performance savings.
key_stories.key_quote: Do we even want the styrofoam before I spent years on fixing the styrofoam?

open_questions.context: Kaze says technique is ‘extremely expensive’ and used sparingly, but did not specify where or how.
questions: Which specific objects currently use shell texturing?
What criteria determine when it’s worth the performance cost?
Any plans to optimise or replace these spots?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions possibly releasing on Steam without Mario assets but gives no concrete plan.
questions: What is the current release strategy (ROM only, PC port, both)?
Has the team begun asset replacement to avoid Nintendo IP?
How will emulator compatibility be handled at launch?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes that unique zipper sounds may require ‘unused sound effects’, unsure if any are left.
questions: What is the current sound-bank memory budget?
How many new effects are still feasible?

open_questions.context: Kaze lists missing ‘peach doodle’ and ‘bowser doodle that shoots flame’ but no follow-up.
questions: What is the design brief for these doodles?
